title: Top 5 Highest Priced Stocks In America
summary:
As not all brokers offer fractional shares of stocks, it's important for retail investors to know what stocks may be difficult to trade due to the high price of each share.
These trading implications can matter even though stock price does not necessarily correspond to the value of a company.
There are the top 5 highest-priced stocks that trade in the U.S., as of May 18, 2020, excluding those sold only on OTC markets.
Key Takeaways A stock price doesn't necessarily reflect the value of the company, since market cap multiplies stock price by the number of shares outstanding.
Here, we list some of the highest priced stocks available on U.S. exchanges, although a company's value and share price must be analyzed using fundamentals.
text:
As not all brokers offer fractional shares of stocks, it's important for retail investors to know what stocks may be difficult to trade due to the high price of each share. These trading implications can matter even though stock price does not necessarily correspond to the value of a company. Because a company's total market capitalization is a product of both its share price and the number of shares issued, the stock price alone tells you little about how overvalued or undervalued a stock is.

There are the top 5 highest-priced stocks that trade in the U.S., as of May 18, 2020, excluding those sold only on OTC markets.

Key Takeaways A stock price doesn't necessarily reflect the value of the company, since market cap multiplies stock price by the number of shares outstanding.

Still, some companies have a low number of shares, and therefore a higher price per share in the market.

Here, we list some of the highest priced stocks available on U.S. exchanges, although a company's value and share price must be analyzed using fundamentals.

Stock Price: $253,500.80

Market Cap: $410.7 billion ﻿ ﻿

﻿ Type of Company: Holding Company Conglomerate

Berkshire Hathaway has the highest-priced shares of any U.S. company, and is also one of the largest companies in the world, consistently ranking in the top 10 by market value. Berkshire was originally a textile company, but was bought by Warren Buffett and is now a holding company for his investments. Among its many holdings are the GEICO insurance company, the BNSF Railroad, and the Lubrizol chemical company. As its CEO, Buffett has famously resisted splitting Berkshire's shares, something companies normally do to make it easier to trade their stock. Buffett instead has kept the price high to make it harder to trade, and thus discourage short-term trading which would increase the stock's volatility. However, in 1996, Berkshire launched a new share class (BRK.B), which has a lower price. This allows people purchase much smaller chunks of the company.﻿﻿ They currently trade for a much more accessible $176.22.

Stock Price: $3050.17

Market Cap: $3.5 billion ﻿ ﻿

﻿ Type of Company: Conglomerate with Focus on Food and Shipping

Seaboard started as a grain milling company in the early 1900's, and went public in 1959. Through a series of mergers and acquisitions it acquired substantial meat production and processing businesses, international shipping businesses, while still keeping grain processing and trading businesses.﻿﻿ Seaboard has never split its shares.

Stock Price: $2795.06

Market Cap: $10.3 billion ﻿ ﻿

﻿ Type of Company: Homebuilding and Mortgage

NVR is a homebuilder and mortgage banking company based in Virginia. Some of the company's subsidiaries include Ryan Homes, Fox Ridge Homes, and NVR Mortgage. NVR Inc. has also never split its stock.

Stock Price: $2,409.78

Market Cap: $1.2 trillion ﻿ ﻿

﻿ Type of Company: Online Retailer and Cloud Services

Amazon started as an online retailer of books, and expanded until it is now an online retailer for virtually everything. In addition to its enormous e-commerce business, Amazon has a dominant position in the cloud computer services industry with Amazon Web Services. Amazon is one of the handful of companies to exceed $1 trillion in valuation, and is consistently among the top 5 most valuable companies on earth. This enormous size is what lets it make this list despite having undergone 3 separate stock splits in the late 1990's which increased its share count 10-fold.﻿﻿

Stock Price: $1835.24

Market Cap: $10.5 billion ﻿ ﻿

﻿ Type of Company: Telecom Service Provider

<div id="byline_1-0" class="comp byline">
By
<a
href="https://www.investopedia.com/gabe-alpert-4774166"
data-tooltip-trigger="true"
class="byline__link--no-short-bio"
>Gabe Alpert</a>
</div>
<div id="displayed-date_1-0" class="comp displayed-date">
Updated May 19, 2020</div>
</div>
</header>
<div id="article-body_1-0" class="comp article-body mntl-block">
<div id="mntl-sc-page_1-0" class="comp article-body-content mntl-sc-page mntl-block" data-sc-sticky-offset="80" data-sc-ad-label-height="0" data-sc-ad-track-spacing="90" data-sc-min-track-height="250" data-sc-max-track-height="600" data-sc-breakpoint="40em" data-sc-load-immediate="2" data-sc-content-positions="[300, 1, 1, 1250, 1, 1]" data-bind-scroll-on-start="true">
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>As not all brokers offer <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/f/fractionalshare.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">fractional shares</a> of stocks, it's important for <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/r/retailinvestor.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">retail investors </a>to know what stocks may be difficult to trade due to the high price of each share. These trading implications can matter even though stock price does not necessarily correspond to the value of a company. Because a company's total <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/marketcapitalization.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="3">market capitalization</a> is a product of both its share price and the number of shares issued, the stock price alone tells you little about how overvalued or undervalued a stock is.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-1" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-2" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>There are the top 5 highest-priced stocks that trade in the U.S., as of May 18, 2020, excluding those sold only on <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/o/over-the-countermarket.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">OTC markets</a>.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-3" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-4" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-callout mntl-block">
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-5" class="comp theme-whatyouneedtoknow mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-callout mntl-block" data-tracking-id="mntl-sc-block-callout" data-tracking-container="true">
<h3 id="mntl-sc-block-callout-heading_1-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block-callout-heading mntl-text-block">
Key Takeaways</h3>
<div id="mntl-sc-block-callout-body_1-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block-callout-body mntl-text-block">
<ul><li>A stock price doesn't necessarily reflect the value of the company, since market cap multiplies stock price by the number of shares outstanding.</li><li>Still, some companies have a low number of shares, and therefore a higher price per share in the market.</li><li>Here, we list some of the highest priced stocks available on U.S. exchanges, although a company's value and share price must be analyzed using fundamentals.</li></ul></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="heading-toc" id="1-berkshire-hathaway-inc-brka"></a> <h2 id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-6" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=BRK.A" class="mntl-sc-block-heading__link" >1. Berkshire Hathaway Inc. (BRK.A)</a> </h2>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-7" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<ul><li>Stock Price: $253,500.80</li><li>Market Cap: $410.7 billion<span class="ql-inline-citation" data-cite="2">﻿</span>﻿</li><li>Type of Company: Holding Company Conglomerate</li></ul>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-8" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-9" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Berkshire Hathaway has the highest-priced shares of any U.S. company, and is also one of the largest companies in the world, consistently ranking in the top 10 by market value. Berkshire was originally a textile company, but was bought by <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/articles/01/071801.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">Warren Buffett</a> and is now a <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/h/holdingcompany.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">holding company</a> for his investments. Among its <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/berkshire-hathaway-s-top-companies-and-brands-4685441" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="3">many holdings</a> are the GEICO insurance company, the BNSF Railroad, and the Lubrizol chemical company. As its CEO, Buffett has famously resisted splitting Berkshire's shares, something companies normally do to make it easier to trade their stock. Buffett instead has kept the price high to make it harder to trade, and thus discourage short-term trading which would increase the stock's <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/v/volatility.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="4">volatility</a>. However, in 1996, Berkshire launched a new share class <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=BRK.B" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="5">(BRK.B)</a>, which has a lower price. This allows people purchase much smaller chunks of the company.<span class="ql-inline-citation" data-cite="1">﻿</span>﻿ They currently trade for a much more accessible $176.22.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-10" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<a class="heading-toc" id="2-seaboard-corp-seb"></a> <h2 id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-11" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=SEB" class="mntl-sc-block-heading__link" >2. Seaboard Corp. (SEB)</a> </h2>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-12" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<ul><li>Stock Price: $3050.17</li><li>Market Cap: $3.5 billion<span class="ql-inline-citation" data-cite="2">﻿</span>﻿</li><li>Type of Company: Conglomerate with Focus on Food and Shipping</li></ul>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-13" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-14" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Seaboard started as a grain milling company in the early 1900's, and went public in 1959. Through a series of <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/mergersandacquisitions.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">mergers and acquisitions</a> it acquired substantial meat production and processing businesses, international shipping businesses, while still keeping grain processing and trading businesses.<span class="ql-inline-citation" data-cite="3">﻿</span>﻿ Seaboard has never split its shares.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-15" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<a class="heading-toc" id="3-nvr-inc-nvr"></a> <h2 id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-16" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=NVR" class="mntl-sc-block-heading__link" >3. NVR Inc. (NVR)</a> </h2>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-17" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<ul><li>Stock Price: $2795.06</li><li>Market Cap: $10.3 billion<span class="ql-inline-citation" data-cite="2">﻿</span>﻿</li><li>Type of Company: Homebuilding and Mortgage</li></ul>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-18" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-19" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>NVR is a homebuilder and <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/mortgage.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">mortgage</a> banking company based in Virginia. Some of the company's subsidiaries include Ryan Homes, Fox Ridge Homes, and NVR Mortgage. NVR Inc. has also never split its stock.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-20" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<a class="heading-toc" id="4-amazoncom-inc-amzn"></a> <h2 id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-21" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=AMZN" class="mntl-sc-block-heading__link" >4. Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN)</a> </h2>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-22" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<ul><li>Stock Price: $2,409.78</li><li>Market Cap: $1.2 trillion<span class="ql-inline-citation" data-cite="2">﻿</span>﻿</li><li>Type of Company: Online Retailer and Cloud Services</li></ul>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-23" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-24" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Amazon started as an online retailer of books, and expanded until it is now an online retailer for virtually everything. In addition to its enormous e-commerce business, Amazon has a dominant position in the cloud computer services industry with Amazon Web Services. Amazon is one of the handful of companies to exceed $1 trillion in valuation, and is consistently among the top 5 most valuable companies on earth. This enormous size is what lets it make this list despite having undergone 3 separate stock splits in the late<strong> </strong>1990's which increased its share count 10-fold.<span class="ql-inline-citation" data-cite="2">﻿</span>﻿</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-25" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<a class="heading-toc" id="5-cable-one-inc-cabo"></a> <h2 id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-26" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=CABO" class="mntl-sc-block-heading__link" >5. Cable One Inc. (CABO)</a> </h2>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-27" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<ul><li>Stock Price: $1835.24</li><li>Market Cap: $10.5 billion<span class="ql-inline-citation" data-cite="2">﻿</span>﻿</li><li>Type of Company: Telecom Service Provider</li></ul>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-28" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-29" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Cable One is a provider of cable, internet, and phone services through its Sparklight and Clearwave brands. It has also never split its stock since it was spun-off from Graham Holdings Company in July 2015.<span class="ql-inline-citation" data-cite="4">﻿</span>﻿</p>
</div>

><span class="link__wrapper">Buyback</span></a>
<div id="related-terms__description_1-0" class="comp related-terms__description mntl-text-block">
A buyback is a repurchase of outstanding shares by a company to reduce the number of shares on the market and increase the value of remaining shares.</div>
<a
href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/buyback.asp"
id="related-terms__read-more_1-0"

<a
href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/r/reversesplit.asp"
id="related-terms__title_1-0-1"
class=" related-terms__title mntl-text-link"
data-tracking-container="true"
><span class="link__wrapper">Reverse Stock Split Definition</span></a>
<div id="related-terms__description_1-0-1" class="comp related-terms__description mntl-text-block">
A reverse stock split consolidates the number of existing shares of corporate stock into fewer, proportionally more valuable, shares.</div>
<a
href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/r/reversesplit.asp"
id="related-terms__read-more_1-0-1"
class=" related-terms__read-more mntl-text-link"
data-tracking-container="true"
><span class="link__wrapper">more</span></a>
</div>

id="related-terms__title_1-0-2"
class=" related-terms__title mntl-text-link"
data-tracking-container="true"
><span class="link__wrapper">How Share Repurchases Can Raise the Price of a Company's Stock</span></a>
<div id="related-terms__description_1-0-2" class="comp related-terms__description mntl-text-block">
A share repurchase is a transaction whereby a company buys back its own shares from the marketplace, reducing the number of outstanding shares and increasing the demand for the shares.</div>
<a

id="related-terms__read-more_1-0-2"

id="related-terms__title_1-0-3"
class=" related-terms__title mntl-text-link"
data-tracking-container="true"
><span class="link__wrapper">Price-to-Earnings Ratio – P/E Ratio</span></a>
<div id="related-terms__description_1-0-3" class="comp related-terms__description mntl-text-block">
The price-to-earnings ratio (P/E ratio) is defined as a ratio for valuing a company that measures its current share price relative to its per-share earnings.</div>

class=" related-terms__title mntl-text-link"
data-tracking-container="true"
><span class="link__wrapper">What the Price-To-Book Ratio (P/B Ratio) Tells You?</span></a>
<div id="related-terms__description_1-0-4" class="comp related-terms__description mntl-text-block">
Te price-to-book ratio (P/B ratio) to evaluates a firm's market value relative to its book value.</div>

data-tracking-container="true"
><span class="link__wrapper">Fundamental Analysis</span></a>
<div id="related-terms__description_1-0-5" class="comp related-terms__description mntl-text-block">
Fundamental analysis is a method of measuring a stock's intrinsic value. Analysts who follow this method seek out companies priced below their real worth.</div>
